NEW YORK —The wild swings in the stock market over the last few weeks have reawakened memories of the technology crash of 2000 in which many small investors lost their savings. But this time around, market experts say, ordinary investors seem less vulnerable than the professionals who have taken a beating.The excesses in the financial markets are now generally believed to reside in complex mortgage securities and other esoteric investments, not in the traditional stock and bond markets where average investors put their money.Overall, analysts say that the situation may well get worse before it gets better. The Standard & Poor's 500 has fallen about 6.4 percent since July 19, when it set a record high.It is considered normal for the market to fall as much as 10 percent periodically during bull markets. That leaves room for the Dow Jones industrial average to fall another 640 points, to 12,600.In the near term, average investors can expect more turmoil and uncertainty in the stock market and may have a harder time obtaining mortgages, especially in the United States. But investment experts say that ordinary long-term investors, as long as they are diversified, should worry less."There is no immediate crisis" for the long-term individual investor, said Michael Poulos, a managing director at Oliver Wyman, a consulting firm that specializes in financial services. "This is mostly a case of relatively rich, sophisticated investors who made big bets on the credit spreads that will have big problems."The credit crisis has reverberated throughout the financial markets, but the greatest impact has been felt by investors in mortgage securities and those involved with corporate buyouts.Also, hundreds of thousands of homeowners are facing resetting rates on loans and may not be able to refinance easily into another loan.Last week, the Federal Reserve and other central banks across the globe lent $293 billion to banks to ensure that there was enough money to lend to borrowers.But even skeptical market watchers acknowledge that stocks, which average Americans buy through mutual funds, appear less vulnerable than the market for complex debt investments typically bought by hedge funds, pension funds and insurance companies.Since bottoming out in late 2002, stocks have risen at a more modest pace than in the 1990s - an average of 13 percent a year. And despite recent losses, the Dow is still up 6.2 percent since Jan. 1.The ratio of stock prices to corporate profits for the S & P 500 is 16.8, slightly above the average of 15.7 since 1935, but below the average of 22.8 since 1988.On numerous occasions in recent decades, stocks have fallen 6 percent or more in a short period. In most cases - the summers of 1998 and 1999, and the winter of 2003, for example - stocks began rising again soon. In a few cases, most notably 2000, the initial declines signaled larger problems.There is no way to predict where the market will go, but many investment specialists say the economy is fundamentally strong.Companies are adding jobs and real wages are rising.Still, the fact that the stock and credit markets are falling despite a vibrant global economy has been unnerving to individual investors.In the short term, investors can probably expect more turmoil.Expectations of future volatility - though they are far lower by one popular measure than they were early in this decade and in the late 1990s - have surged to their highest levels in more than four years."Certainly for young folks, this is a shocker," Jim Swanson, chief investment strategist at MFS Investments in Boston, said about volatility. "But the 20-year numbers suggest that this is a return to normal."Individual investors should figure out how comfortable they are with the risks of their investments, while considering their financial circumstances and investment goals, advisers say.Many financial experts suggest investors consider moving their money to less risky investments like Treasury notes and blue-chip stocks, which they expect to now perform better than junk bonds and smaller stocks.But they caution against impulsively buying and selling stocks based on a short-term market swing."None of us are going to be able to time our moves," said Liz Ann Sonders, chief investment strategist at Charles Schwab. "If you take a more systematic approach, then you are sort of putting yourself on the right side of the market. But it's not human nature to do that. We love to ride our winners until something happens."For now, anxiety is particularly high among well-heeled investors in some hedge funds that have reported losses. Many are flocking for the exits, forcing portfolio managers to sell otherwise solid investments.And the demands could intensify this week: Wednesday marks 45 days before the end of the quarter, the deadline by which most hedge fund investors must notify the funds if they want to redeem their investments.Stock prices could also decline further if investors no longer expect the big premiums that private equity firms have been paying to buy public companies.To place the current period in context, many experts are studying the credit crisis in 1998, when Russia defaulted on its debts and the hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management collapsed."In 1998, 60 subprime companies went out of business," said Meredith Whitney, an analyst with CIBC World Markets. "And that didn't send our economy into a recession."In fact, the stock market climbed higher after the Fed intervened to save Long-Term Capital and the International Monetary Fund lent money to Russia.Other market watchers, however, contend that employment and profits are often lagging indicators and that the American economy is already slowing, along with growth in consumer spending.As adjustable-rate mortgages are reset, many U.S. homeowners will face higher monthly housing payments. That could force some families to cut back on spending.Sallie Krawcheck, head of global wealth management at Citigroup, said ordinary investors should be "making adjustments for risk and, if appropriate, exploring possible buying opportunities."They should focus on whether "the market volatility bleeds over into the health and behavior of consumer," she said. "That is the key for the real economy."David Leonhardt contributed reporting.

FRANKFURT —The rest of Europe may be deep into its annual summer hiatus, but the Frankfurt headquarters of the European Central Bank has been a hive of activity since Thursday, when the bank thrust itself into a market rattled by fears of a credit crisis.On Monday, the bank injected €47.7 billion, or $65 billion, into the financial system, its third emergency operation since last week, to keep European money markets from drying up. That came after a landmark injection of €94.8 billion Thursday morning.These bold and costly moves have put a spotlight on the European Central Bank, which has traditionally played a supporting role to the Federal Reserve in global financial crises. This time, the Europeans acted earlier, and on a far larger scale, than either the Fed or central banks in Asia.Some market commentators have accused the central bank of panicking, and said its intervention could send the wrong signal to hedge funds or other institutions engaged in risky investing by suggesting they could expect to be bailed out.Yet its remedy seems to have worked - at least as a short-term measure to prevent the problems in the United States mortgage-lending market from swamping the broader markets in Europe. The Federal Reserve and the central banks of Japan and Australia also injected funds into the market.In a statement Monday, the European Central Bank said "money market conditions are normalizing."Several economists said the bank had little choice but to respond on a huge scale after it became clear early Thursday that banks in Europe were unable to obtain credit in a market spooked by the disclosure of European losses from the U.S. subprime market."Possibly they overdid it," said Erik Nielsen, the chief European economist at Goldman Sachs in London. "But if they had done less, and we had a systemic crisis, they would have been blamed for it."Nielsen described the bank's intervention as a "textbook example of what to do when trouble emerges."To some extent, the European central bank's central role was simply dictated by the clock. The crisis in confidence set off by the mortgage-lending problem reached a critical stage Thursday morning in Europe, hours before the markets opened in the United States.The first players to feel the credit crunch were European banks, seeking to borrow in dollars. The lack of liquidity drove up the overnight borrowing rate to 4.6 percent, well above the bank's benchmark rate of 4 percent.For days, European investors had been unnerved by disclosures that banks and investment funds here faced losses because of exposure to mortgage-related investments. BNP Paribas's announcement on Thursday that it would suspend operations of three funds tipped the market into havoc."The problem is, these funds looked like normal euro money market funds," said Thomas Mayer, the chief European economist at Deutsche Bank. "That led to a loss of trust in the market."Like the Fed, the ECB keeps in daily touch with officials at commercial banks. Through these contacts, it became aware of the deepening distress in the market. Some observers, including Nielsen, suspect the ECB's top leaders were also warned about the crisis directly from senior executives at major European financial institutions.However the information trickled in, the decision to intervene in the market was made by the bank's executive board, a six-member committee chaired by the bank's president, Jean-Claude Trichet. Officials at the ECB said Trichet had been closely involved in the recent operations.In a sign of its success, the bank's moves brought the overnight borrowing rate quickly back to 4 percent."It looks like a very successful operation to stabilize the money market," Mayer said. "The Fed has had slightly more trouble. On Thursday, they injected too little, and on Friday, they overcompensated."After the European bank's initial injection of €94.8 billion at a rate of 4 percent - its first such intervention since the aftermath of the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks - the subsequent tenders on Friday and Monday represent a type of mopping up, Nielsen said.The bank is essentially rolling over a portion of the loans it issued on Thursday. The fact that it is injecting less each day indicates that it is gradually withdrawing from the market.The big question now is whether the bank will adjust its policy to account for the market mayhem. After its last policy meeting in early August, as the crisis was in an earlier stage, Trichet signaled the bank would raise rates by a quarter point, to 4.25 percent, in September.Whether the bank chooses to put that increase on hold depends on whether markets calm down. On Monday, most European markets were up more than 2 percent. The Bank of England, in its first statement since the crisis began, said it did not plan to inject funds into the system."The climate of distrust could blow over, with proper central bank action," Mayer said. "What will remain is a more sober calculation of credit risk. When a credit bubble deflates, you hit hard bumps."Mayer said he doubted the mortgage-related problems would, by themselves, undermine Europe's robust economic performance. Deutsche Bank projects Europe's economy will grow 2.8 percent in 2007, easily outstripping the United States, which is projected to grow 2 percent.But he says that contrary to recent popular belief, a sharp slowdown in the United States would affect Europe."The good news is that real estate markets do not affect each other," Mayer said. "But as real estate financing tightens up, it affects all real estate markets, not just in the United States."

SINGAPORE —If there is a crisis in global financial markets, it was not apparent in Asia on Monday.Some of the region's biggest markets sprang back after Friday's slide, with Australia's benchmark index gaining 1.3 percent and South Korea's rising 1.6 percent. Bourses in Europe opened higher, also following Wall Street's stabilization on Friday.Reflecting the perverse logic that governs markets of late, Japan's Nikkei 225 stock average rose on news that the country's economic growth was slowing - suggesting borrowing costs will remain low and friendly to business - and that the central bank had lent an additional $5 billion to banks to ensure they have enough cash.Commodity prices also recovered after declining on concerns that hedge funds were selling their positions to cover losses related to the U.S. subprime mortgage market.All in all, it appeared that moves in recent days by the world's biggest monetary authorities - the Federal Reserve, the European Central Bank and the Bank of Japan - to avert a shortage of cash in global markets by lending money at cheap rates had worked for the time being.The Bank of Japan on Monday announced that it would again put more funds in the market. The Reserve Bank of Australia and the ECB followed suit.Last week, concerns about growing losses in the ailing U.S. market for subprime mortgages to risky borrowers prompted many investors in Asia to yank funds out of any investments considered relatively less safe, either because they involved emerging markets or because they were tied to high levels of debt.The recovery encouraged some analysts to sound a note of optimism Monday. They pointed to a growing awareness that Asia is still flush with funds and does not suffer from the same reliance on debt as investors do in Europe and the United States."The worst of it's behind us in Asian markets," said Adrian Mowat, a strategist at JPMorgan in Hong Kong. "Asian monetary systems have been relatively flush with cash, and growth here is typically being funded by earnings - household and corporate, rather than debt funding."Others, however, warned that more surprises could be in store for the region and that Monday's recovery might in retrospect be only a temporary respite. "We think the volatility will continue for a while," said Hans Goetti, head of research strategy at Citi Private Bank in Singapore.There was an air of battening down in Asia on Monday, analysts said, with investors selling stocks in some smaller markets and buying stocks in larger economies, especially financial and commodity-related stocks that had been pushed down last week."As information flows out, people are waiting to see what happens next," said Rahul Malhotra, managing director for private banking in the Middle East and Pacific Rim at Merrill Lynch in Singapore. Merrill's advice to its clients, Malhotra said, was not to join the panic selling, advice he said most appeared to be taking.Indeed, some analysts said the latest declines provided an opportunity to buy Asian stocks more cheaply. "I like these types of events because the market overreacts," said Mowat. "The comments that come across in the media are overstating what the real impact is."Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index climbed back part of the way after falling 3.7 percent Friday, its biggest drop in six years, to a three-month low. Traders said moves by the Federal Reserve and by Australia's own Reserve Bank of Australia to ensure adequate liquidity restored confidence among investors.The Australian dollar climbed as well after the Reserve Bank raised its outlook for inflation, increasing the likelihood that it would raise interest rates.Because metals are Australia's largest export, the Australian dollar also tends to move with commodity prices. Prices for oil and copper rose Monday amid signs of growing demand from China and falling global stockpiles.The Australian dollar also climbed against the Japanese yen, following data showing the Japanese economy slowing. Investors interpreted that as a sign that the Bank of Japan was less likely to raise interest rates to curb inflation, prompting them to push the benchmark stock index up 0.21 percent.The Bank of Japan said Monday that it had lent banks an additional ¥600 billion, or $5.07 billion, to help ensure adequate funding in the interbank market, after pumping ¥1 trillion into the market Friday. Central bankers in Australia and South Korea said they stood ready to inject funds if warranted. But outside of Japan and Australia, there have been no signs that central bankers are putting funds into the market or moving to defend their currencies. That could be because no other Asian countries are as deeply involved in the global credit boom as Japan and Australia.Japan is the source of much of what is known as the carry trade, in which investors borrow funds in Japan, where interest rates are very low, and invest them in countries where interest rates are relatively high or where currencies are rising, such as Australia.Analysts and economists have long surmised that hedge funds are particularly fond of this strategy. Thus, as their exposure to the deteriorating U.S. subprime mortgage market became evident, many investors have anticipated that hedge funds would reverse their carry trades, selling assets around Asia and repurchasing Japanese yen.Japanese domestic investors, however, are also taking advantage of this strategy, analysts say, so news that the Japanese economy is not taking off is also good news for smaller markets around the region. It means Japanese investors will not necessarily be pulling their funds back to Japan anytime soon.Analysts say investors in Asia should take comfort in what they said was a lower regional exposure to the kinds of credit risks battering some hedge funds and lenders in the United States and Europe.The amount of exposure to the U.S. subprime markets that Asian financial institutions have announced so far remain small, analysts said. "There's nothing we've seen that makes us worry about the scale and implications of it," Mowat said.Analysts stressed that purchasing credit derivatives had become a standard hedging strategy among large financial institutions in Asia, just as it had in the West. Most financial firms have a percentage of assets that are nonperforming at any given time. So the kinds of losses and write-downs anticipated because of the decline in the U.S. housing market were not extraordinary, they said.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 14 (Dow Jones) — The Bank of Japan drained 600 billion yen ($5 billion) from the money supply Tuesday morning, after pumping money into the system for two days to ease fears of a liquidity crisis.The bank injected 1 trillion yen on Friday and an additional 600 billion yen Monday. Central banks in Europe, the United States and Australia also pumped cash into the system in the face of credit fears set off by the subprime mortgage meltdown in the United States.The Japanese bank took the action after the overnight call rate stood Tuesday morning at 0.1 percent, far below the target of 0.5 percent, a sign of excess liquidity in the system, said a bank official, Hirotaki Hideshima.The goal is to bring the rate back to 0.5 percent, he said, but it is too soon to gauge the impact.“Rates were trading low this morning, so as a natural response we’re absorbing funds,” Mr. Hideshima said. “Yesterday and today the rates were strong after we provided funds, so this is just a symmetric response.”On Monday, he said it was possible that the rise Friday and Monday in the overnight rate — an indication that banks had grown more cautious about lending — was tied to the subprime problems abroad.On Tuesday, however, Mr. Hideshima said reports that the Bank of Japan’s injections were part of a concerted global effort to head off a credit crisis had been overblown. The injections and draining are part of the central bank’s normal operations each day, he said.One analyst at a foreign investment bank said Tuesday’s low rate showed that banks no longer expected the Japanese central bank to raise interest rates this month and that the pace of future rate increases will slow as the concerns about subprime lending ripple through global financial markets.

SYDNEY —The global fallout from the collapse of the U.S. market for risky mortgages deepened Tuesday, with two Australian lenders warning investors and consumers of troubles in their businesses.Rams Home Loans Group said it was forced to pay more to cover its financing due to "unprecedented disruptions" in U.S. financial markets in recent weeks. The mortgage company said that if market volatility continued, the effect on Rams's earnings was "likely to be material."The chief executive of Bluestone Mortgages, a second Australian lender that is carrying a large number of loans to clients with histories of credit problems, warned of similar difficulties during an interview with an Australian newspaper. Alistair Jeffery, the lender's chief, told the newspaper, The Australian, that he expected to pass higher funding costs on to the consumer.Bluestone did not return calls seeking comment.Concerns about problems at Rams weighed on markets throughout Asia on Tuesday. A broad measure of stocks in Asia, the Morgan Stanley Capital International Asia-Pacific index, declined 0.2 percent to 149.05 by early evening in Tokyo. (Page 13)Bourses in Europe also opened lower. Concerns about turmoil in financial markets heightened after UBS, the Swiss bank that is one of Europe's largest, said that "turbulent" markets could cut into profit later this year."This is a global issue that has emigrated out of the U.S., and there has been a contagion effect and it has impacted corporates who are funded through the U.S. debt market," Nick Hughes, an analyst with UBS in Sydney, said when asked about widening problems in the Australian market.The news from Rams marks the first time that ripples in the financial markets have so clearly crossed over into fields that affect ordinary consumers in the Asia-Pacific region.Until now, the damage in Australia had been limited to two investment funds that were forced to bar withdrawals and a third that announced that it had to sell assets to prevent it from falling afoul of its loan obligations.Although neither Rams nor Bluestone Mortgages is suffering from increased rates of default in their domestic markets, both have fallen victim to the crisis of confidence in global debt markets set off by the collapse of the subprime loan market in the United States.An increase in the number of defaults by subprime borrowers - typically homeowners with low credit ratings - has triggered falls in asset prices in the broader credit markets.Lenders are now more wary of risk, leading to so-called higher spreads, in which loans with greater risk are charged at higher interest rates and less money is being lent.Rams, which has 14.6 billion Australian dollars, or $12 billion, worth of loans, said in a statement that it was still too early to say how much the turmoil in the credit markets would affect its bottom line. The group stressed that it had continued to be able to grant loans, but said that it was having to pay more to secure the money."Given the current volatility in the global debt markets, the directors believe that it is premature to determine with certainty the extent of the likely negative financial impact on Rams for the 2008 financial year. However, if current market conditions continue, it is likely to be material," the group said in its statement.Shares of Rams, which just last month were listed on the stock exchange for the first time, dropped 34 cents, or 19 percent, to 1.41 dollars Tuesday.Australia, which has more sophisticated financial markets than many of its Asian neighbors, and so greater exposure to the U.S. turmoil, has been particularly badly hit.John Edwards, chief economist at HSBC in Sydney, said he believed Australia would eventually pull through the current crisis."We haven't had significant default rates, and we didn't have a burst of subprime-type lending: 100 percent against valuation, no employment checks and things like that," he said. "But there are follow-on effects that everyone is feeling that I think will be transitory."

FRANKFURT —The European Central Bank on Tuesday declared recent financial market turmoil largely over, a sign that the bank was likely to proceed with a plan to lift borrowing costs in early September to curb inflation caused by a rising economy.The liquidity crunch during the past week, which the ECB and other central banks smoothed over with massive cash infusions, had led many investors to reassess whether the ECB would tighten credit when it meets Sept. 6.But the president of the ECB, Jean-Claude Trichet, in a rare and formal written statement, said Tuesday that "market conditions have gone progressively back to normal," as private lenders were beginning to resume their normal routine of extending regular credit to worthy borrowers.Trichet added that investors had heeded his call two weeks ago to "maintain their composure.""This attitude has been welcome and effective in the recent days," Trichet said. "It will help consolidate a smooth return to a normal assessment of risks in liquid markets."At the same time, the German central bank said that the effect on the largest economy in the euro-zone from the mortgage losses in the United States that triggered the current crisis will be "limited overall."Trichet's statement highlighted how, within the ECB, decision-makers saw no contradiction in supplying liquidity and then raising rates soon thereafter.The first measure is short-term and largely technical, designed to strengthen trust among banks that, panicky about the spillover, had squeezed their overnight lending to one another. But higher interest rates, while they do tighten credit, work in the medium term to control inflation, the bank's main priority.Still, the bank is leaving itself an escape hatch. Earlier this month when Trichet first hinted at a September rate increase, he emphasized more than usual that the central bank would not "pre-commit" itself to a rate hike - least of all during uncertain times."It still depends on whether we return to stability in the markets," said Kenneth Wattret, chief euro-zone economist at BNP Paribas in London, said of the possibility of a September rate increase. "If we go back to a period of turmoil, it's hard to believe they would raise."The ECB has lifted borrowing costs eight times since the end of 2005, to 4 percent, as the European expansion gained momentum. Higher interest rates have also helped lift the value of the euro, causing concern among politicians, mainly in France, that the ECB might be quashing the recovery."The paradox is that with its strategy of rate rises the ECB is at the same time making credit more expensive," a former finance minister of France, Thierry Breton, said Monday, Reuters reported.Yet if the ECB abandons plans for lifting rates in September, it could fan further concern that the central bank is privy to bad news not yet made public."If the bank now delays its rate increase," said Kenneth Broux, an economist at Lloyds TSB in London, "it will create suspicions it knows something that the markets do not."New data released Tuesday showed that the pace of economic growth in the 13-nation euro-zone slowed in the second quarter to 0.3 percent - about half the rate of the first quarter. France and Germany, the two largest euro members, also registered 0.3 percent growth during the same period, less than economists had forecast, but in line with the ECB prognosis of steady growth that would allow it to raise its benchmark rate by a quarter percentage point.Despite the slowing, Axel Weber, the president of the German Bundesbank, said Tuesday that losses related to the collapse of the U.S. subprime mortgage sector would be "limited overall."IKB Deutsche Industriebank, a small German bank, sent shudders through markets recently when a default gave rise to a government-engineered rescue. But Weber said other German financial institutions are sound."We have confirmed our impression that the increased risks in certain market segments are insulated and that the profit impact for credit institutions is limited overall," Weber said. The recent problems at IKB are a one-time case, he said, specific to that institution.Taken together, the statements by the Bundesbank and the ECB appeared to be a broad offensive aimed at closing the door on short-term panic and easing the way for stability.The ECB, injected €7.7 billion in one-day liquidity into the system Tuesday, a far smaller amount than the €94.8 billion it infused Friday into seized-up markets. The reduced amount of cash is a sign that the market for overnight loans among private banks is largely functioning without the ECB.Weber's statement was aimed at assure markets that no more surprises along the lines of IKB are in the offing, since markets feared German lenders might be hiding greater losses. In the next few days, many European companies will need to roll over short-term debt, but that will only happen if investors are confident the worst is over."The most important step is to ease the 'information crunch' that has almost paralyzed markets in the last few days," said Marco Annunziata, chief economist for UniCredit in London. "The German banking system was in the spotlight."Other events Tuesday also suggested the worst of the current crisis may have passed.Two Australian lenders, Bluestone Mortgages and Rams Home Loans Group, said that their earnings would take a hit as a result of financial market gyrations, while Swiss giant UBS said that its profit would probably decline for the same reason. But the news did not trigger a broad sell-off, as it might have only a week ago.

If there is a crisis in global financial markets, it was not apparent in Asia and Europe Monday. And on Wall Street, the week got off to an unremarkable start.Stock prices were up moderately but broadly in the United States for most of the day, with little of the volatility that had characterized the markets last week. But the major indexes shed their modest gains late in the trading session and finished the day not far from where they closed on Friday.When trading ended, the Dow Jones industrial average closed down 3.01 points, at 13,263.53. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 stock index and the Nasdaq composite were each off 0.1 percent or less.A number of early developments appeared to help put investors at ease Monday. Before the market opened, the government reported that retail sales rose in July at a solid pace. With mortgage markets tightening and home values dropping in many parts of the country, some economists have questioned whether consumer spending could stand up.Also, Goldman Sachs moved Monday to shore up one of its hedge funds that has suffered huge losses in the recent market turmoil. The investment bank said it and other investors would add $3 billion to the fund.Separately, the Federal Reserve Monday added more money into the financial system, providing $2 billion in loans in an effort to help calm the markets.Financial stocks were a drag on the market Monday. Countrywide Financial, the nation's largest mortgage lender, closed at $26.61, down 4 percent, and Fannie Mae was off 3.5 percent at $64.12.Technology equipment and telecommunications stocks were among the strongest performers. EMC, the data storage company, was up 7.5 percent to $19.05 ahead of the initial public offering of its VMware unit this week. Hewlett-Packard gained 2.6 percent to $48.43, and Sprint Nextel was up 3.4 percent at $19.49.In Europe Monday, stock indexes in Paris and Frankfurt finished about 2 percent higher, and British stocks were up almost 3 percent.The day's tone was set in Asia, where some of the region's biggest markets sprang back Monday after a slide last Friday. They were helped by the slight recovery in American markets after the close of Asian markets late last Friday.Australia's benchmark index gained 1.3 percent and South Korea's main index rose 1.6 percent.Reflecting some of the inverse logic that seems to govern markets of late, Japan's Nikkei 225 Stock Average index closed slightly higher on news that the country's economic growth was slowing, and that the central bank had lent an additional $5 billion to banks to ensure adequate funds in the money market.Central banks from Australia to the United States made similar loans Monday. The European Central Bank added $65.3 billion to the markets Monday.Last week, concerns about growing losses in the ailing market for subprime mortgages in the United States prompted many investors in Asia to take funds out of any investments that were considered relatively risky, either because they involved emerging markets or because they were tied to high levels of debt.The recovery Monday encouraged some analysts to sound a note of optimism. They pointed to a growing awareness that Asia is still flush with funds and doesn't suffer from the same reliance on debt as investors do in Europe and the United States."The worst of it's behind us in Asian markets," said Adrian Mowat, a strategist at J.P. Morgan in Hong Kong. "Asian monetary systems have been relatively flush with cash and growth here is typically being funded by earnings — household and corporate, rather than debt funding."Others, however, warned that more surprises could be in store for the region and that Monday's recovery might in retrospect be only a temporary respite."We think the volatility will continue for a while," said Hans Goetti, head of research strategy at Citi Private Bank in Singapore.There was, therefore, still an air of uncertainty in Asia Monday, analysts said, with investors selling stocks in some smaller markets and buying stocks in larger economies, especially financial and commodity-related stocks that had been pushed down last week."As information flows out, people are waiting to see what happens next," said Rahul Malhotra, managing director for private banking in the Middle East and Pacific Rim at Merrill Lynch in Singapore.Merrill's advice to its clients, Malhotra said, was not to join the panic selling, advice he said that most appeared to be taking.

LONDON —UBS, Europe's largest bank, on Tuesday painted the grimmest picture yet of the downside to recent market jitters on earnings, raising concerns about the sustainability of profit growth across the investment banking sector.The bank, based in Zurich, said in reporting its second-quarter earnings that if the current market turbulence continued throughout this quarter, it expected weak results from its investment banking arm, which represented a third of its pretax earnings. It said it expected "predictable earnings" from its other main businesses, wealth and asset management. "This makes it likely that profits in the second half of 2007 will be lower than in the second half of last year" UBS said.European banks, including BNP Paribas of France and IKB Deutsche Industriebank of Germany, this month were hit by the effects of the U.S. subprime lending crisis. Earnings at investment banks, which have enjoyed record returns from a boom market, might decline as recent market jitters prompt fewer share sales, refinancing of loans and lending for leveraged buyouts, which could hurt the market for mergers and acquisitions."It is inevitable that it will be more difficult for investment banks because you could have hardly had better conditions in the markets at the beginning of the year," said Richard Scott, a fund manager at Iimia Investment Group in Britain.UBS shares fell 2.55 Swiss francs, or 3.9 percent, to close at 63.50 Swiss francs, or $52.48, in Zurich on Tuesday, the lowest level in a year, leading shares of other banks lower.UBS' dim outlook is as much the result of last week's market slump affecting most investment banks as its disproportionately high exposure to the U.S. subprime market, some analysts said."It's a challenging market for all investment banks but there are some that stand out and on this side of the Atlantic it's UBS," said Kinner Lakhani, an analyst at ABN AMRO in London.UBS may have been unlucky with the timing of its earnings statement because it came after a turbulent two weeks in the financial markets. Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse Group, which both reported better-than-expected earnings at the beginning of this month, also mentioned more difficult market conditions but remained optimistic about long-term growth prospects. UBS did not discuss the longer term, focusing on the year's second half.Some analysts, including Matthew Clark at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in London, said there was more to it than just timing. UBS is more exposed to the struggling U.S. subprime market than many of its European counterparts. Recent investments in its fixed-income operation have further weighed on earnings, as the bank hired staff in a boom market, driving up costs.U.S. subprime mortgage losses this year prompted the collapse of Dillon Read Capital Management, a UBS hedge fund operation, and led the bank to book losses connected to the fund for a second quarter in a row. But even after Dillon Read, UBS might be hurt by the fallout from the U.S. mortgage woes.The UBS market outlook overshadowed otherwise positive earnings that beat some analysts' estimates. Profit in the quarter through June rose 79 percent to a record 5.62 billion francs, helped by private banking and a gain from the sale of a stake in Julius Baer Holding.

Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market spread again yesterday — this time to a type of short-term security held by money market mutual funds. These funds have become the investment of choice for many people seeking a safe haven.Standard & Poor’s, the ratings agency, warned yesterday that it might downgrade several issuers of commercial paper, a short-term I.O.U. by companies that promise to repay loans typically within a few weeks to a year.In these cases, S.& P. said, the commercial paper was backed by residential mortgages.The amount of commercial paper in the United States has grown to $2.2 trillion, according to Lehman Brothers, with about $1.2 trillion backed by residential mortgages, credit card receivables, car loans and other bonds. The major buyers include pension funds, insurance companies, hedge funds and short-term money market funds.Investors have flocked to money market funds as they try to avoid volatile stocks and the seized-up bond market. Last week, more than $36 billion moved into money market funds, the largest shift since December 2005. In all, some $2.6 trillion is in money market funds, according to AMG Data Services.Such funds are sold to investors as the equivalent of cash, and their $1-a-share net asset value is considered inviolate. But if the funds experienced big losses, the value of the assets could be vulnerable.The S.& P acted a day after a $1.6 billion cash-management fund run by the Sentinel Management Group halted redemptions because it could not sell its assets at what it considered acceptable prices.Until recently, the crisis in the credit markets has been limited to problems related to subprime mortgages, those given to borrowers with questionable credit histories. But as these troubles seep into other parts of the securities markets, fears of losses are rising in unexpected places.The borrowers, companies that issue asset-backed commercial paper, have found it highly profitable. These companies usually have used the money they borrow to buy securities like slices of mortgage pools that generated yields much greater than the interest paid to the short-term lenders.But there are several risks. First, the companies that issue short-term notes backed by assets with considerably longer terms are exposing themselves to the risk that the interest they earn will not exceed the amount they must pay to their lenders. Perhaps more significant, the borrowers must be concerned about possible losses in the assets they buy, especially when investors will no longer lend them money by buying their commercial paper.The S.& P. highlighted three issuers of commercial paper for possible downgrading. Broadhollow Funding, which was set up by American Home Mortgage Investment, a lender that filed for bankruptcy last week; KKR Atlantic Funding Trust and KKR Pacific Funding Trust, two affiliates of the buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts; and Ottimo Funding, an affiliate of Aladdin Capital Management, an investment manager in Stamford, Conn.Kohlberg Kravis declined to comment yesterday.Ottimo Funding holds about $3 billion in residential mortgages, all rated AAA. George Marshman, chief investment officer at Aladdin, said: “It’s a negotiation process. We’re working with all the investors to make things as orderly as possible. I’m optimistic we can get a good outcome.”Among the money market funds that held commercial paper issued by the companies singled out for possible downgrading were two offered by Evergreen Investments. As of May, the $16.6 billion Evergreen Institutional Money Market Fund held $385 million in Broadhollow Funding and $72 million in Ottimo Funding. The $4.5 billion Evergreen Prime Cash Management Money Market Fund held $50 million in Ottimo Funding as well.A spokeswoman for Evergreen declined to comment.Legg Mason’sMaster Portfolio Trust Liquid Reserves Portfolio, a $52.5 billion fund, owned almost $200 million in securities issued by Ottimo Funding and $750 million in KKR Atlantic Funding.Mary K. Athridge, a Legg Mason spokeswoman, said in a statement: “The holdings represent less than 1.4 percent of the portfolio. We believe the current disruption in the marketplace is liquidity-related rather than credit-related, which the Fed has stepped into the market to address.”As of May 31, Columbia Funds Series Trust Cash Reserves, a $62 billion fund, had a $120 million stake in Ottimo Funding and $400 million in KKR Pacific Funding Trust. A Columbia Management spokesman did not return calls for comment.“If the stigma of mortgage-related extendable-asset-backed commercial paper spreads to asset-backed commercial paper as a whole, you could see bailout events,” said Peter G. Crane, president of Crane Data, the publisher of a newsletter about money market mutual funds. But he added: “The stuff that the money funds are invested in are the highest quality, so it’s the last thing to have trouble.”However, the investment strategies that once were considered conservative no longer are.The Sentinel fund that banned redemptions Monday advertised itself as risk-averse. In a letter to investors, Sentinel said that it had hoped to ride out the troubles but was unable to do so.“We are concerned that we cannot meet any significant redemption requests without selling securities at deep discounts to their fair value and therefore causing unnecessary losses to our clients,” the letter said. “We will continue to monitor the markets and we will raise cash as opportunities present themselves.”Sentinel officials did not return calls for comment.Douglas A. Kass, general partner of Seabreeze Partners Management, an investment firm in Palm Beach, Fla., said the Sentinel disclosure and upheaval in commercial paper markets are examples of the risks investors take when they reach for higher yields.“This is symptomatic of a whole body of investors, including money market and cash management funds, that are attempting to enhance yields, and this is the downside to that journey,” he said.On Monday, Coventree, a Canadian financial services company, said it could no longer issue asset-backed commercial paper because of a liquidity squeeze. In a statement, the firm said that “problems that initially seemed isolated to a few U.S. subprime mortgage lenders have led to broader concerns relating to debt capital markets generally,” including the market for Canadian asset-backed commercial paper.Coventree extended maturities on 250 million Canadian dollars ($237 million) and sought emergency funding for an additional 700 million Canadian dollars ($664 million).In its third-quarter financial statement yesterday, Coventree said: “Certain liquidity providers have advanced funding, some have disagreed that they have an obligation to fund, some are in discussions with the company, and some have not responded. There is no assurance that the liquidity providers will fund or be obligated to fund under the requisite liquidity agreements.”Canadian companies have issued 170 billion Canadian dollars ($161 billion) in commercial paper, according to a Lehman Brothers research report citing Bank of Canada data. About 116 billion Canadian dollars ($110 billion) of that market is asset-backed commercial paper, up from 66 billion Canadian dollars ($63 billion) at the beginning of 2005.

BEIJING —China's industrial output slowed more than expected in July after tax changes made exports less attractive, suggesting to some economists that the country's politically sensitive trade surplus could shrink in coming months.The output growth of 18 percent, which came a day after a strong rise in retail sales, could point to softness in fixed-asset investment when monthly figures are released Thursday, some economists said."With external demand and private consumption proving resilient, the modest easing in industrial production momentum could be due to some moderation in domestic investment growth in July," said Qian Wang, an economist with JPMorgan Chase in Hong Kong.Economists said the slower pace of output did not change the broader policy picture.Many expect the central bank, which has raised interest rates three times so far in 2007, to do so again this quarter to rein in inflation, which has jumped to a 10-year high of 5.6 percent because of runaway food prices.However, policy makers will also be aware of the shadows cast over the world economy by the fallout from the crisis in the U.S. subprime mortgage market. Another worry is the booming China stock market, which keeps defying gravity.Economists said that unsettled global market conditions could explain why the central bank in recent weeks has halted the yuan's steady climb, making the currency more or less mark time.Factories churned out 18 percent more goods than in July 2006, down from 19.4 percent growth in June, the National Bureau of Statistics said Wednesday.Economists had expected a rise of 19.2 percent."The surprising slowdown in industrial output was partly caused by the reduction in export tax rebates," said Zhao Qingming, an economist with China Construction Bank in Beijing.China scrapped or cut tax rebates, effective July 1, on nearly 3,000 export lines, including metals and textiles, to help reduce its record trade surplus and discourage companies from making low-value, energy-intensive goods.In fact, export growth accelerated in July, but economists said this was due to companies shipping goods that had been ordered before the tax changes were announced.But with China's official survey of manufacturers showing declines in overseas orders and industrial output for three months in a row, many economists believe that exports will lose steam over the rest of 2007."As manufacturers expect export growth to decline, they are now cutting their production a month ahead of time," said Gene Ma, chief economist with China Economic Business Monitor, an independent research house in Beijing.Yet another safety scandal concerning Chinese goods - this time the recall of millions of toys by Mattel because of lead paint and small magnets that could be swallowed and cause injury - may also hurt demand for made-in-China goods.Ma said China would be hit by widening credit market strains if they sap U.S. economic growth and thus reduce demand for Chinese goods. Mingchun Sun at Lehman Brothers in Hong Kong agreed."Given the turmoil in global financial markets and uncertainty in the global economic outlook, Chinese exports may be facing tougher times in the future," he said.

FRANKFURT —A day after the European Central Bank made a concerted effort to calm financial markets, stocks retreated worldwide Wednesday, as investors pondered whether the worst news about the deteriorating U.S. mortgage industry had passed.Major market indexes in the United States declined more than 1 percent, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing below 13,000 for the first time since April 24.Financial stocks led a broad retreat, highlighting the hypersensitivity of markets reacting to news that in calmer times might be ignored.The corporate woes of the day began when two of Japan's biggest banks, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial, reported losses on investments connected to U.S. subprime lending, which serves borrowers with spotty credit records.The troubles were compounded in Australia, where Basis Capital Fund Management told investors that losses at one of its hedge funds might exceed 80 percent, as creditors obliged the company, based in Sydney, to sell assets, according to Bloomberg News.Later in the day, the U.S. market, which had been rising, was shaken by a Merrill Lynch report which said that Countrywide Financial, a leading U.S. mortgage lender, could face bankruptcy if liquidity worsened. Merill downgraded the stock to "sell" from "buy," sending its shares down 13 percent.Investors worldwide appeared fearful that the subprime crisis in the United States might worsen there, or lead to new manifestations abroad. The instability there was exported through securities backed by now-questionable mortgages, and the prospect that another big fund - or even a bank - might report new losses weighed heavily on the market."This is a great intransparency we now have to live with," said Ralf Grönemeyer, an equity strategist at Commerzbank in Frankfurt. "Until we know more about where the losses are or could be, what can we do?"Goldman Sachs sized up the depth of the potential problem with a calculation that there was roughly $110 billion in European exposure to securities from the U.S. mortgage market. Only 20 percent of that is from the subprime sector, and spread out over many investment funds and a few banks, but markets in such securities have creaked to a halt, making it impossible to value them or to use them as collateral for short-term lending.The result is one more uncertainty in a world that, over all, appears set to notch up solid growth this year."From a trading perspective, it is very difficult to keep to the big picture in mind," said Jens Nordvig, a senior global markets economist with Goldman Sachs in New York. "In these situations there is tremendous uncertainty about variables that people do not have to worry about normally."The Nikkei 225 stock average in Japan fell by almost 2.2 percent Wednesday to its lowest point in nine months. Stocks in Hong Kong, Australia and Taiwan all fell by around 3 percent.On a day marked by holidays in Italy, Luxembourg, Greece and Austria, benchmark national indexes slid across most of Europe. The CAC 40 in France fell 0.7 percent, while the FTSE 100 in Britain lost 0.6 percent. In Germany, the Dax rose 0.3 percent.The Dow industrials, which rose above 14,000 in July, fell 167.45 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 12,861.47. The S&P 500-stock index fell 1.4 percent, wiping out its gains for the year, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 1.6 percent.Despite the declaration Tuesday from the European Central Bank that the immediate crisis was all but over, a tense atmosphere of uncertainty - mixed, perhaps, with slight foreboding - pervaded financial markets. Panic was not evident, but neither was a renewed appetite for risk, an essential element in closing the door on any financial crisis.European traders sold financial industry stocks, after some analysts downgraded their recommendations on UBS, the Swiss bank that said Tuesday the market turmoil would hurt earnings, and Deutsche Bank, a company that derives a large share of its profits from trading in what is now an extremely volatile market.Events Wednesday bore out the ECB's assessment the previous day that tensions had passed in the overnight lending market, which has been buoyed by the liquidity infusions since last Thursday. The ECB injected no fresh cash into the market Wednesday, while some Asian central banks even began mopping up some excess liquidity, and the U.S. Federal Reserve put $7 billion into the market, a tiny sum by its standards.With the overnight lending easing into its normal rhythm, attention was turning to whether the market for "commercial paper," the short-term debt used to finance day-to-day operations, would follow suit. Toward the end of the month, much short-term debt typically falls due, raising the specter of a mass shortage of credit.Standard & Poor's, the ratings agency, warned Tuesday that it might downgrade several issuers of commercial paper. That same day, a Canadian fund manager, Coventree, sent a scare through markets when it said it could not sell a planned issue. The company ultimately said it found buyers for $557 million in debt.The trillion-dollar hedge fund industry remained another source of doubt in investor minds. These lightly regulated pools of money work under few disclosure requirements, and give their investors limited windows in which to withdraw their money.Robert Howie, head of European hedge fund research at Mercer Investment Consulting in London, said, "We should be able to get better visibility towards the end of this month or the beginning of next."Also amid the turmoil, the euro has given back some of its gains after reaching record levels above $1.38 in July.The euro fell below $1.35 Wednesday, only a few weeks after traders actively discussed the possibility it would go to $1.40. Recent data showed that European growth slowed in the second quarter."One of the big factors over the last year has been money flowing into European stocks," said Chris Turner, head of foreign exchange research at ING Baring. "So if the cyclical story doesn't look quite as positive, that has an impact on the euro."Julia Werdigier in London and Wayne Arnold in Singapore contributed reporting.
